news_summary: New lunar samples from Chang’e-6 have provided groundbreaking insights into a massive impact that reshaped the Moon’s interior.
news_summary_fr: De nouveaux échantillons lunaires provenant de Chang'e-6 ont fourni des informations révolutionnaires sur un impact massif qui a remodelé l'intérieur de la Lune.
news_summary_es: Las nuevas muestras lunares de Chang'e-6 han proporcionado información revolucionaria sobre un impacto masivo que remodeló el interior de la Luna.

articles.title: Chang’e-6 lunar samples reveal a giant impact reshaped the Moon’s interior
articles.summary: A colossal ancient impact may have reshaped the Moon far more deeply than scientists once realized. By analyzing rare lunar rocks brought back by China’s Chang’e-6 mission from the Moon’s largest crater, researchers found unusual chemical fingerprints pointing to extreme heat and material loss caused by a giant impact. The collision likely stripped away volatile elements, reshaped volcanic activity, and left a lasting chemical signature deep below the surface.
articles.content:
Ever since the Moon formed, asteroid strikes have played the leading role in shaping its surface. These collisions carved out vast craters and basins and altered the Moon's landscape and chemistry. What scientists have not fully understood is how deeply these enormous impacts affected the Moon beneath the surface.

To explore that question, a team led by Prof. Hengci Tian from the Institute of Geology and Geophysics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (IGGCAS) analyzed lunar basalt samples returned by Chang'e-6 (CE6). These rocks came from the South Pole-Aitken (SPA) Basin, the largest and oldest known impact basin on the Moon. The samples stood out immediately because their potassium (K) isotopic makeup was heavier than any lunar basalts previously collected by the Apollo missions or found in lunar meteorites.

Why Potassium Holds Clues to Ancient Impacts

Potassium is considered a moderately volatile element, meaning it can partially evaporate under extreme heat. During a massive impact, temperatures soar, allowing potassium to vaporize and its isotopes to separate. This process leaves behind a chemical record that can reveal the intensity of the impact, the conditions during the event, and how the collision changed materials in the lunar crust and mantle.

With this in mind, the researchers focused on measuring the isotopic composition of potassium in the Chang'e-6 samples.

Chemical Evidence of a Giant Collision

The results, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), link the unusual potassium signature directly to the colossal impact that created the SPA Basin.

Using high-precision techniques, the team measured potassium isotopes in four basalt fragments with sapphire collision-cell multicollector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICP-MS). All of the CE6 samples showed elevated δ41K values, ranging from 0.001 ± 0.028‰ to 0.093 ± 0.014‰ (mean: 0.038 ± 0.044‰, 2SE). This average is about 0.16‰ higher than values measured in Apollo lunar basalts (-0.13 ± 0.06‰, 2SE), which are widely considered representative of the lunar mantle and the Bulk Silicate Moon.

Ruling Out Other Explanations

To determine what caused this enrichment in heavier potassium isotopes, the researchers examined three possible factors. They evaluated long-term exposure to cosmic rays, changes during magma evolution, and contamination from meteorites. Each of these processes was found to have only a minimal effect, well within measurement uncertainty, and none could account for the chemical shift seen in the samples.

A Lasting Impact on Lunar Volcanism

The analysis instead points to large-scale loss of volatile elements during the SPA-forming impact, particularly through potassium evaporation. This depletion may have reduced magma production on the Moon's far side, helping explain why volcanic activity has long been more extensive on the near side than on the far side.

Computer simulations supported this interpretation. They showed that the impact not only dug deep into the lunar crust and possibly the mantle but also released enough heat to drive convection within the Moon's interior.

What This Means for the Moon and Beyond

Together, these findings show that the impact that formed the South Pole-Aitken Basin profoundly altered the Moon deep below its surface. More broadly, the study underscores how massive impacts can shape the internal chemistry and evolution of rocky planets and moons throughout the solar system.

The research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, the CAS Youth Innovation Promotion Association, and other sources.

articles.personality_title: Chang’e-6 mission reveals giant impact changed the Moon’s inside
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Moon’s surface was shaped by many asteroid hits over billions of years. Scientists knew these impacts made big craters, but they weren’t sure how deeply they changed the Moon beneath the surface.

**What happened** – Scientists studied rocks brought back by China’s Chang’e-6 mission from the Moon’s largest crater, called the South Pole-Aitken Basin. They found unusual chemical signs in the rocks, especially in potassium, an element that changes when heated a lot. These signs showed the crater was made by a huge impact that heated and changed the Moon’s inside.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that the giant collision not only made a big crater but also caused the loss of some elements and changed volcanic activity deep inside the Moon. It helps explain why the Moon’s far side has less volcanic activity than the near side. The findings also give clues about how big impacts can affect other planets and moons.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely study more samples from the Moon and other places to understand how large impacts shape planets over time. This could improve our knowledge of the history of the Moon and the solar system.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Rocks from Chang’e-6 reveal that a massive ancient impact reshaped the Moon’s interior, changing its chemistry and volcanic activity.
articles.personality_title_fr: La mission Chang’e-6 révèle qu’un impact géant a modifié l’intérieur de la Lune
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La surface de la Lune a été façonnée par de nombreux impacts d’astéroïdes pendant des milliards d’années. Les scientifiques savaient que ces impacts créaient de grands cratères, mais ignoraient jusqu’où ils modifiaient l’intérieur de la Lune.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont analysé des roches ramenées par la mission chinoise Chang’e-6 depuis le plus grand cratère lunaire, le bassin du Pôle Sud-Aitken. Ils ont trouvé des signes chimiques inhabituels, notamment dans le potassium, un élément qui change sous une chaleur intense. Ces indices montrent que ce bassin provient d’un impact énorme qui a transformé l’intérieur de la Lune.

**Impact** – Cette découverte prouve que l’impact géant a non seulement formé un grand cratère, mais aussi provoqué la perte de certains éléments et modifié l’activité volcanique profondément sous la surface lunaire. Elle explique pourquoi le côté éloigné de la Lune a moins de volcans que le côté proche. Ces résultats éclairent aussi comment de gros impacts affectent d’autres planètes et lunes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont probablement étudier d’autres échantillons lunaires et d’autres corps célestes pour mieux comprendre comment les grands impacts influencent l’évolution des planètes. Cela améliorera nos connaissances sur l’histoire de la Lune et du système solaire.

**En une phrase** – Les roches de Chang’e-6 montrent qu’un impact ancien et colossal a remodelé l’intérieur de la Lune, modifiant sa chimie et son activité volcanique.
articles.personality_title_es: La misión Chang’e-6 revela que un gran impacto cambió el interior de la Luna
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La superficie de la Luna fue moldeada por muchos impactos de asteroides durante miles de millones de años. Los científicos sabían que estos impactos crearon grandes cráteres, pero no estaban seguros de cuánto cambiaron el interior de la Luna.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de científicos analizó rocas traídas por la misión china Chang’e-6 desde el cráter más grande de la Luna, llamado la Cuenca Polo Sur-Aitken. Encontraron señales químicas extrañas en las rocas, especialmente en el potasio, un elemento que cambia cuando se calienta mucho. Estas señales mostraron que el cráter fue causado por un impacto enorme que cambió el interior de la Luna.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que la colisión gigante no solo creó un gran cráter, sino que también causó la pérdida de algunos elementos y cambió la actividad volcánica en el interior de la Luna. Ayuda a explicar por qué el lado lejano de la Luna tiene menos volcanes que el lado cercano. Los resultados también dan pistas sobre cómo los grandes impactos afectan otros planetas y lunas.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores probablemente estudiarán más muestras de la Luna y otros lugares para entender cómo los grandes impactos moldean los planetas con el tiempo. Esto podría mejorar nuestro conocimiento sobre la historia de la Luna y el sistema solar.

**Una frase clave** – Las rocas de Chang’e-6 muestran que un impacto antiguo y enorme remodeló el interior de la Luna, cambiando su química y actividad volcánica.
